section.title: Question tags
section.sectiontitle: We usually put negative question tags after affirmative sentences and affirmative tags after negative sentences.

section.title: Question tags
section.sectiontitle: If the main sentence has an auxiliary verb e.g. is, can, etc., this is repeated in the question tag.
section.sectiontitle2: If the main sentence has no auxiliary verb, the question tag is a form of the verb do.

section.title: Question tags
section.sectiontitle: If the tag is a real question (we want to know something and are not sure of the answer), use a rising intonation.
section.text2a: I'm next in the queue, aren't I?
section.sectiontitle2: If the tag is not a real question (we already think we know the answer), use a falling intonation.
section.text4a: Those sunglasses are terribly expensive, aren't they?

section.title: Question tags
section.sectiontitle: The question tag for I am is aren't I? The question tag for let's is shall we?.
section.text2a: Let's walk along the beach, shall we?
section.sectiontitle2: After imperatives we often use won't you? to invite people to do things.
section.text4a: Take a copy of the brochure, won't you?

section.title: Question tags
section.sectiontitle: After negative words like never, no, hardly, etc., we use an affirmative question tag.
section.text1a: You never want to go out to clubs, do you?
section.sectiontitle2: After nothing we use it in question tags. After nobody, somebody and everybody we use they.
section.text4a: Nobody wants to go out tonight, do they?
